awd_titl_txt: Psychopharmaceuticals and Medicated Soldiering in America's post-9/11 Military
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States military has seen an unprecedented and marked turn to the use of psychiatric medications by service personnel in the post-9/11 wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. In 2006, the US Department of Defense developed for the first time official criteria for the use of FDA-approved psychiatric medications "in theater", in the physical and tactical spaces of military operations including active combat. Conservative estimates suggest that 1 in 6 service members is now taking at least one psychiatric medication. The use of psychiatric medications by the US military has attracted public attention, and is poised to influence the ways that Americans think about soldiering and the nature of war. Studies on the topic remain largely theoretical and center on the ethics of military psychiatric medication use. This project aims to understand how these medications are prescribed and used in practice, as well as how military service members understand medication effects on the work of counterinsurgency. The results from this study will have important implications for public knowledge and policy, as well as for veteran advocates and clinical practice aimed at the post-service transition of veterans. The project fosters the inclusion of underrepresented student veterans in military and veteran-related academic research and to support diversity in social and behavioral science. It will do so by 1) mentoring student veterans, 2) bringing together researchers and veterans in a symposium to address ways forward for collaborative research, and 3) publishing a co-edited volume on this important topic. 

Dr. Jocelyn Chua of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will explore how psychiatric medications have been assimilated into the operations, infrastructures and norms of post-9/11 counterinsurgency, how these medications are understood and experienced by soldiers, and what impact these medications have had on the cultural landscape of soldiering in the U.S. Given the Army's prescription trends and prominent role in ground combat operations compared with other military branches, the research will focus on the US Army, Army Reserve, and Army National Guard. The PI and research team will use in-depth interviews, focus groups, and ethnographic observation to understand the formal and informal ways that psychiatric medications are being prescribed, accessed, used, and shared. The research team will also assess enlisted soldiers' experiences of psychiatric medication use in deployment and their evaluations of the propriety of these medications to counterinsurgency soldiering. The PI will also conduct archival research to contextualize current military psychiatric medication use within the recent history of the practice of US military behavioral and mental health. Research will be based in North Carolina and Washington, DC. Home to four military bases, including Fort Bragg Army base, North Carolina currently has the third highest number of active duty and reserve members of all US states. The National Archives and the National Library of Medicine in Washington, DC and Maryland, respectively, house extensive military resources for the archival research. Findings from this research will illuminate how psychiatric medications are used in deployment and soldiers' own accounts of their use in order to determine the extent to which theoretical concerns and public debate align with the experiences and concerns of soldiers themselves.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Jocelyn Lim Chua, a sociocultural medical anthropologist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, studied the uptake and lived effects of psychopharmaceutical use by the United States military in the post-9/11 wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.  In 2006, the US Department of Defense developed for the first-time official criteria for the use of FDA-approved psychiatric medications “in theater” – in the physical and tactical spaces of military operations including active combat.  Shifting practices regarding psychopharmaceutical use on the battlefield raises questions of broad public significance about medication use and soldiering and medicalized treatment for mental health on the battlefield.

There were two major goals of this project.  The first was to describe the assimilation of psychiatric medications into the operations, infrastructures, and ethical norms of post-9/11 US counterinsurgency in Iraq and Afghanistan and the resulting lived experiences of their use by US Army personnel using semi-structured, qualitative interviews and ethnographic fieldwork.  Including data collected during a preliminary research phase prior to this award, the project resulted in 125 interviews and 2 focus groups with active duty, National Guard and Reserve Army personnel and Army veterans.  One hundred sixteen of these interviews were conducted with NSF funding.  Research materials also included ethnographic fieldnotes at military health conferences and professional trainings, archival research notes, and over 3,000 of pages of documents obtained through FOIA request.  The second major outcome of the project was to advance research opportunities for military-affiliated students and student veterans to foster their inclusion in military and veteran-related academic research and to support diversity in social science research, more broadly.  This project did so through: 1) the training and mentoring of four undergraduate students in qualitative research data collection and analysis, and 2) the collaborative planning and execution of a 2-day symposium on the theme of “Engaging Military Communities.”  The symposium gathered over 20 participants from across the US, including advocates, clinicians, students, artists, and researchers, to reflect and engage on the opportunities and challenges of working within and/or with military-affiliated and veteran communities from within and beyond the academy.

Findings from the study documented significant variability in how military personnel view and assess the role, risks, and advantages of psychopharmaceuticals in deployment, and in soldiers’ ability to access psychopharmaceuticals in deployed settings.  Interviews with both healthcare providers and enlisted soldiers and officers simultaneously emphasized the portability and dispensability of psychopharmaceuticals in a deployed setting, while also pointing to access challenges, breaks in supply and the consequent effects for providers’ scope of care and patients’ medication experience.  Complicating research on the stigmatization of mental health and mental health care in the military, findings from this study show that concern for psychopharmaceuticals among deployed soldiers is highly context-dependent, shaped by shared perceptions of risk, vulnerability and safety that are not necessarily always stigmatizing and which exceed focus on the individual alone. 

Findings from this study contribute to anthropological scholarship in three primary areas: 1) the anthropology ofpharmaceuticals, 2) the intersections between medicine, war, and US empire, and 3) the anthropological study of biomedicine, particularly by bringing attention to the practice of military medicine.  The research has resulted in 4 peer-reviewed journal articles and another 2 peer-reviewed articles, 2 chapters in edited volumes, and a book manuscript that are currently in progress.  The project also contributed to the training of several graduate students in methods of qualitative analysis.

This study has generated practical, previously unknown information about practices surrounding the prescription and use of psychopharmaceuticals in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.  This data will be valuable to inform public debate and ethical analysis by offering qualitative insight into how medications have been prescribed and used during the global war on terror, and how soldiers understand and evaluate medication effects on the work of soldiering.  Key findings from this study have been shared at national conferences and through presentations and talks with regional and national organizations attended by clinical and community stakeholders.
